0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Eaton-Lambert syndrome: 10 to 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 3 or 4 divided doses; titrate gradually up to 35 mg/kg/day or to intolerable side effects

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy in pediatric patients have not been established

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• bone marrow suppression, dose-related and with fatalities, may occur; monitoring recommended; discontinue therapy if bone marrow suppression occurs
  • behavior disorders have been reported
  • concomitant use with drugs causing bone marrow suppression should be avoided
  • gastrointestinal adverse effects have been reported and may preclude use
  • renal function, changes may occur; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Guanidine: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Guanidine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Atrial fibrillation
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Leukopenia, Myelosuppression, Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Liver function tests abnormal
  • Psychiatric:Psychotic disorder
  • Renal:Interstitial nephritis, acute, Interstitial nephritis, chronic, Serum creatinine raised, Tubular necrosis, acute, Uremia

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Following a nerve impulse, guanidine hydrochloride enhances acetylcholine release and also slows the rate of depolarization and repolarization of muscle cell membranes, which reduces muscle weakness and fatigability.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in fatigue and muscle weakness indicates efficacy
  • CBC with differential at baseline and frequently during therapy
  • urine examinations and serum creatinine measurements

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report signs or symptoms of bone marrow suppression (anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia).
  • Instruct patient to report signs or symptoms of new onset or worsening renal dysfunction.
  • Warn patient to immediately report signs or symptoms of emotional lability, a psychotic state, confusion, mood changes, or hallucinations.
  • Drug may cause paresthesias, nervousness, irritability, tremors, flushing, rash, sweating, palpitations, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • Counsel patient to report severe gastrointestinal symptoms (dry mouth, gastric irritation, anorexia, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramping).
